response.answer_text: In terms of you not paying for access to the software then, yes, it’s free. However, you have to give them your email address to get access, so they’ll likely market paid products to you over time. You also then have to spend time to learn how to use and to then actually use the software. The more time and, therefore, money you invest in it, the less likely you are to want to switch to something else later. However, with free software, what you can do will still will be limited in some way (reduced functionality or support are the common ones). Then, when something doesn’t work and you’re fed up of waiting for support, then $5 (or whatever a month), won’t seem too steep for short-cutting the system - that’s what some upgrades offer (not necessarily GoogleDocs and G Suite - I haven’t gone that far, but that’s what free is for). It’s to entice you, to dangle that carrot in front of your nose. Then there’s the thing called the Law of Reciprocation, too. It’s quite interesting and because they’ve now done something ‘nice’ for you, it’s human nature for you to be more inclined to return the favour at some point. Of course, with something like free software, it’ll be to upgrade to the paid version. (Get Robert Cialdini’s book, Influence, if you’re interested in learning more about the Law of Reciprocation.) Google can wait for you… they’re not going anywhere for now - it’s a long sales process. The longer it goes on, the more time you invest in Google products. *** As an aside, it always make me laugh when Mac users claim that they don’t have to pay for Apple Pages and the rest of them - “Oh, they’re ‘free’ software for Mac users. Who wants to pay for Windows, right?”. Sure. It’s free when you’ve bought their hardware. However, they selectively choose to ignore that part (I have both pc and Mac, so try and stay objective when possible).*** A much longer answer than I anticipated but, yes, in the first instance, GoogleDocs is ‘free’.
Yes, if you have a Google account, then you can use Google Drive, which includes Docs, Spreadsheets, and presentation. These services do not charge for your use.
